Sir J.E.Chancellor, .C.M..G. ,B.S.O., ............. seoretar]-.. principal assistant secretary, C.I.D. THE SITUATION IN THE NEAR EAST.
THE MUDANIA CONFERENCE.
1. With reference to Cabinet 62 (22), Conclusion 1, the Prime Minister informed the Cabinet that no telegram had yet been received from Mudania, and in the circumstances he felt that no useful purpose would be served by discussing the terms of the Armistice.
THE PROPOSED PEACE CONFERENCE.
2. With reference to Cabinet 61(22), the Prime Minister asked the Secretary of State for foreign Affairs if he desired to continue the discussion of the arrangements for the Peace Conference.
Lord Curzon on deprecated continuing the discussion of the Peace Conference arrangements at present. He sent a telegram to the High Commissioner at Constantinople asking him for his views on certain points and he was unwilling to advise the Cabinet on the subject until he had received a reply from Sir Horace Rumbold and had considered his suggestions. Lord Curzon mentioned that the Turks, who want no Allied troops on missions when they arrive in Thrace, had made a suggestion that in place of an Allied occupation of Eastern Thrace for 30 days, the Allies should take over the administration of Eastern Thrace for 45 days, after which it should be handed over completely. This proposal was also preferred by the Greeks. The Greeks also had made a proposal that the line in Eastern Thrace should be that fixed In 1915,that is to say, to the East of the Maritza River.(General Harington's telegram D.29).
Lord Curzon, in reply to a question as to how far M. Venizelos directed Greek policy, informed the Cabinet that M. Venizelos, in reply to a request from the Greek Goveinraent that he should representthem &broad,haii imposed certain conditions "beforeaccepting the post. The Greek Government had nowconsented to the conditions imposed by Venizelosso that he is now the official representative of greece abroad and would, in all probability, repre-sent Greece at the Peace Conference,It was agreedTo await the receipt cf a telegramfrom Sladania and the reply of theSigh Commissioner to'the telegramof the Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs before continuing the dis-cuseion of the arrangements for thePeace Conference.2, Whitehall Gardens, s.w.1,/110th Oeteber,lt*
